Location: Fortified camp outside Granada city

The afternoon sun beat down on the Castilian camp, the September heat lingering despite the approach of autumn. From the elevated command platform, Granada sprawled before you—massive walls, the Alhambra fortress gleaming red on its heights, the Nasrid green banners hanging limp in the still air. Fifty thousand souls behind those walls. Nine thousand soldiers. Four to six months of food, if the estimates were accurate.

Ãlvaro de Luna stood beside you, studying the city through narrowed eyes. "Word from the Master of Calatrava arrived an hour ago. The breach at Motril is complete. He expects surrender within two days, three at most. Then Salobreña." He paused. "By mid-September, every coastal port will be ours. Granada will be completely landlocked."

From the command tent behind you came the sounds of the camp—soldiers drilling, smiths hammering, the low hum of an army that had learned to wait patiently. Twenty-one thousand men who had survived four and a half months of grinding attrition. The fortifications they'd built were impressive: earth ramparts, elevated crossbow platforms, proper siege lines. Not a temporary camp, but a statement of permanence.

"The garrison's behavior has shifted," Don Fadrique reported, gesturing toward the northern gates visible from your position. "No sorties in six days. Their cavalry formations that used to contest our every movement now stay close to the walls. They're watching us, calculating."

MartÃ­n—Commander MartÃ­n ibn Ahmad, who had once defended Granada's fortresses and now advised you—approached with his characteristic measured tread. "Your Majesty, if I may observe: Sultan Yusuf knows mathematics as well as we do. Once the ports fall, the timeline becomes inevitable. He faces a choice between negotiating surrender from a position of some dignity now, or waiting until his people are starving and desperate in January or February." He paused. "The question is whether his pride, or his nobles' pressure, allows him to make that choice."

The question hung in the air: Did you wait for the Sultan to send envoys, letting hunger do its work? Or did you take the initiative, offering terms before the situation became more desperate?

What is your approach?

The command went out across the camp within minutes. Trumpets sounded the assembly—not the call to battle, but something different. The call for crusaders.

From every corner of the fortified positions, they came. The sworn crusaders, those who had taken formal vows in churches across Christendom. Perhaps two hundred men now, after casualties and attrition—Italians, Germans, French, Portuguese, English, and Castilians bound by a shared oath. They assembled in formation, their white crosses brilliant against varied surcoats.

The Military Orders formed beside them with professional precision. The Master of Santiago's knights, black crosses on white. Calatrava's red crosses. Alcántara's green. Perhaps eight hundred knights total, the warrior-monks who had fought the Moors for generations. Master Luis de Guzmán rode forward, his eyes gleaming. "Your Majesty commands, and Santiago answers."

Fray Hernando brought the white banner himself, the Guardian Company forming its escort. The silk caught the afternoon light, pristine despite months of campaigning. Behind it, the reliquaries—the True Cross fragment and Santiago's bone in their gold and silver.

Your squires brought the white Milanese armor, piece by piece. The weight settled on your shoulders with familiar pressure—breastplate, pauldrons, vambraces, the full harness of a Christian king making formal demand. The white plume fixed to your helmet. Your father's sword at your side, Non Nobis Domine etched in the steel.

Ãlvaro watched the assembly with something like awe. "A thousand warriors under crusader banners and white armor. If this doesn't move them..." He didn't finish the thought.

The white flag of truce went up—a pure white standard carried by one of the Guardian Company. The formation began to move: the white banner at the center, you beneath it in white armor, crusaders and Military Orders arrayed in disciplined ranks, the reliquaries gleaming.

The march toward Granada's northern gate took perhaps ten minutes. Long enough for the garrison to see what was coming. Long enough for alarm bells to ring from the walls. Long enough for word to spread through the city that something unprecedented was approaching.

You could see figures gathering on the battlements—hundreds of them, soldiers and citizens alike drawn by the spectacle. The green Nasrid banners stirred in a slight breeze. The gates remained closed, but a cluster of officers appeared on the wall above them, ornate armor catching the sun.

The formation halted perhaps eighty yards from the gate—close enough to be heard clearly, far enough to demonstrate peaceful intent under the truce flag. The thousand men behind you fell silent with professional discipline. The white banner snapped once in the breeze, the only sound.

A figure on the wall stepped forward—older, wearing the rich armor of high rank, a commander's authority in his bearing even at this distance. Other officers flanked him, perhaps a dozen men of obvious importance. They were studying you, studying the formation, calculating what this meant.

The silence stretched. Granada waited. Your army waited.

The gates before you held the last Muslim kingdom in Iberia.

You compare our Sultan to yourself, as if his choice to defend his people is the same as your choice to invade them. You invoke Allah's name while demanding we surrender everything our faith has held sacred in Al-Andalus for seven hundred years."

His voice rose slightly, carrying to the walls where hundreds watched. "And then—then—you remind us that you are 'fully prepared to siege and starve the city.'
